level01.intro:
From a terminal shell, you can almost always type '<toolname> --help' to determine command line syntax and additional switches/flags/options used with the tool.
It's worth noting that --help may only provide a high-level summary of how to use the tool, or perhaps just the most commonly used switches/flags/options.

Example: ping --help
level01.prompt: What is the first command line flag/option (e.g., -a, -B, -c) you see?

level02.intro:
From a terminal shell, you can almost always type 'man <toolname>' to determine command line syntax and additional switches/flags/options used with the tool. It's similar to --help, but man (which stands for 'manual') typically provides much more granular and verbose help. If you don't get the help you need from --help, man is your next best choice.

Example usage: man ping
level02.task: Use man with the tool ssh
level02.prompt: What is the command argument (i.e., -a -b -c) used to request compression of all data over SSH?

level03.intro: The 'ls' command allows users to list directory contents. So if you want to see what files exist at your current location, just run 'ls'
level03.task: Using the ls command, find out what files are in your current directory.
level03.prompt: What's the name of the file you see?

level04.intro: Linux supports hidden files, which start with a period. For example '.hidden' will not show up when running 'ls'.
level04.task: Run 'man ls' and find the switch that will list hidden files.
level04.prompt: Which switch will show all files, including hidden files?

level05.intro: The current directory has a hidden file in it.
level05.task: Use ls with a single switch to find out which hidden file is in the current directory.
level05.prompt: What's the name of the hidden file you see?
